item.title: Phil Rothfield calls for NRL to issue Dylan Walker life ban if convicted for assault - Sporting News AU
item.description:
Phil Rothfield calls for NRL to issue Dylan Walker life ban if convicted for assault  Sporting News AU

Prominent journalist Phil Rothfield has put pressure on the NRL to hand Dylan Walker a life ban should the Manly centre be found guilty in his domestic violence ...

NRL star Dylan Walker has been charged with bashing his fiancee amid reports she was seen cowering in the street. Former Miss Universe Australia finalist ...

Manly Sea Eagles chief executive Lyall Gorman talks about the alleged domestic violence incident involving Dylan Walker.

item.description:

Manly chief executive Lyall Gorman says he has spoken to the fiancee of Dylan Walker after the Sea Eagles star was charged with assaulting her at their home ...

The Manly player to appear in court on December 11.

The Manly Sea Eagles centre was arrested at a home on the Northern Beaches on Thursday evening.

item.title: Walker reveals respect for Scott - League - Inside Sport
item.description:
Walker reveals respect for Scott - League  Inside Sport

Curtis Scott might have broken his eye socket with a punch, but Dylan Walker isn't holding it against him. Scott and Walker's fight during Manly's match against ...

item.title: NRL Player Dylan Walker Charged For Assaulting Partner - Ten Eyewitness News
item.description:
NRL Player Dylan Walker Charged For Assaulting Partner  Ten Eyewitness News

Rugby League player, Dylan Walker, has been charged by police. He was arrested last night and accused of attacking his fiancee, while she held their baby son ...

item.title: Walker’s career on the line - The Australian
item.description:
Walker’s career on the line  The Australian

Three years ago, he was fortunate to escape with his life after an ill-informed decision to dabble with prescription drugs. Now Dylan Walker is fighting to save his career. Walker was charged with assaulting his fiancee Alexandra Ivkovic — the mother of his four-month-old son — in the early hours of Friday morning, Manly immediately standing him down from training as they digested another setback in a year that was already an annus horribilis. They have had players breaking curfew, coaching dramas and now the nadir — allegations that Walker left Ivkovic with cuts to her hands and her feet a...

item.title: Dylan Walker stood down by Manly following arrest for assault charges - The Guardian
item.description:
Dylan Walker stood down by Manly following arrest for assault charges  The Guardian

Manly NRL star Dylan Walker has been stood down from training after being charged with assault following an alleged domestic violence incident involving his partner on Sydney’s Northern Beaches. The woman, 24, suffered minor cuts to her shoulder, leg and feet at a home in Dee Why, on Thursday afternoon and was treated by paramedics at the scene. Related: Wayne Bennett 'happy to be sacked' by Brisbane Broncos Walker, also 24, was later arrested and charged with common assault and assault occasioning actual bodily harm. The Sea Eagles centre was driven away from Manly Police Station by coach ...

item.title: Panthers save finals hopes - The Australian
item.description:
Panthers save finals hopes  The Australian

The Sea Eagles were a victim of their own ill discipline, with Trent Barrett’s side losing the penalty count 12-4 as they suffered their first road loss of the year. The Panthers must now win five of their last eight to be any hope of making the top eight after bouncing back from their flogging at the hands of South Sydney last week. The game was tinged with controversy, with questioning of Dallin Watene-Zelezniak’s 37th minute four-pointer in which he pulled the ball from the grasp of teammate Waqa Blake and appeared to lose possession. But the dubious calls went both ways, with Watene-Zel...

item.title: Rob Sutherland’s SuperCoach team - The Advertiser
item.description:
Rob Sutherland’s SuperCoach team  The Advertiser

And while you’re on a hiding to nothing revealing your team ahead of team list Tuesday (TLT), in order to justify spending hours of my working week trawling through the stats on NRL SuperCoach Gold I was told I had to write this article. Without further ado — The Belalie Beasts HOOKER Cameron Smith ($523,700) Hands down the best hooker in the game. In the past six years Smith has only averaged below 70 once (68.6 in 2015), has averaged over 75 four times and produced over 1500 points each year. A set and forget option and safe captaincy choice every week he plays. Will miss four games over ...

item.title: Roosters star thwarted by penis - The Advertiser
item.description:
Roosters star thwarted by penis  The Advertiser

The Roosters star was caught being betrayed by his penis on live television early in the first half against Manly. A wide pass out to Blake Green led to a kick through the Roosters’ defence, but the ball travelled too far for the Manly backs to clean it up and score a try. Kenny-Dowell followed the kick, waiting to see if it would go dead, but his trouser companion got a little too close for comfort as the ball swiped past his shorts. The traitorous act forced the Roosters into a line dropout, giving back Manly the possession over a 20m restart in Sydney’s favour. Kenny-Dowell made up for h...

item.title: Manly take some big steps forward - The Advertiser
item.description:
Manly take some big steps forward  The Advertiser

As painful as their exit from the finals may have been, this was a great step forward for the club as they look to build around skipper Daly Cherry-Evans, the Trbojevic brothers and powerful forward Martin Taupau. KENT: Refs made mistakes, Sharks made more BUZZ: Greenberg has his head in the sand WHERE THEY FINISHED After some hairy moments in the final few weeks, Manly steadied to finish sixth on the ladder. Penrith eliminated them from the finals courtesy of a controversial late try to Tyrone Peachey. WHAT WENT WRONG Manly’s discipline was an issue throughout the season. They were one of ...

item.title: What we learned from weekend NRL trials - The Advertiser
item.description:
What we learned from weekend NRL trials  The Advertiser

Get all the best info in our wrap of all the final weekend of pre-season. PANTHERS 18 d EELS 6 1. PEACHEY ON FIRE: Expect Tyrone Peachey to start the season in the centres. Peachey was at his elusive best against the Eels, regularly beating defenders with his silky footwork. Panthers coach Anthony Griffin was highly impressed with his performance, strongly indicating the City Origin representative will commence the season in the centres. “The other guys have got to get passed him (Tyrone),” Griffin said. “He finished the year as a great centre for us and his game last week in the All Stars ...

item.title: Sea Eagles unlucky, but not the way you think - The Advertiser
item.description:
Sea Eagles unlucky, but not the way you think  The Advertiser

The Panthers took the lead via a contentious try to Tyrone Peachey in the dying stages, a decision that will be the talking point for some time to come. Here’s where the game was won and lost. 1) PENRITH BUILD PRESSURE BUT NOT POINTS The Panthers forwards really stepped up early with Trent Merrin and James Tamou putting the Sea Eagles on the back foot by winning the contact in the middle of the field. However despite a plethora of early possession, including a couple of repeat sets, they weren’t able to their early penalty goal. COSTLY: Penrith land controversial winner CLOSE CALL: Melbourn...

item.title: Late Mail: Tedesco out, Raiders shock - The Advertiser
item.description:
Late Mail: Tedesco out, Raiders shock  The Advertiser

With the Blues No.1 out Kevin Naiqama moves to fullback for the Tigers and Malakai Watene-Zelezniak is recalled to the wing. In Saturday’s first match-up the Roosters and Sharks are both one to 17 with Kane Evans and Chris Smith dropping out of the Roosters’ line-up while Sam Tagataese and Jeremy Latimore miss out for Cronulla. In other news: * Dumped former Newcastle captain Trent Hodkinson will end a seven-game NRL exile against Wests Tigers with young playmaker Brock Lamb will make way for Hodkinson. * James Tedesco(ankle) will not play for the Tigers, and Kevin Naiqama will deputise at ...

item.title: Father’s faith is Mitchell’s motivation - The Advertiser
item.description:
Father’s faith is Mitchell’s motivation  The Advertiser

The former first grade hopeful, now living in Taree, who had his promising rugby league career at South Sydney cut short due to homesickness. It’s a real life story that drives Latrell to reach the game’s greatest heights and make his dad proud. More significantly, it’s why being rested last week won’t deter this rising Rooster from achieving his goals. Footy Pass promo ROOSTERS READY DUGAN RAID This determined drive was rammed home over the Easter break when Latrell spent two days fishing with his father back home in Taree on the NSW mid-north coast. According to Mitchell senior, the quali...

item.title: Dally M count: top five players at every club - The Advertiser
item.description:
Dally M count: top five players at every club  The Advertiser

While it seemed foregone conclusion for Smith, there were still plenty of surprises in the team of the year — not least Cowboys dynamo Jason Taumalolo missing out due to a shoulder charge back in round 2. Check out the top five vote-getters in the Dally M Medal at every NRL club, and scroll down for round-by-round voting below. Due to a technical issue, the votes for the Roosters and Knights aren’t appearing. The top five vote-getters at both clubs are as follows: KNIGHTS Daniel Saifiti 8 Brock Lamb 8 Mitchell Barnett 7 Sione Mata’utia 5 Danny Levi 4 Jamie Buhrer 4 Dane Gagai 4 ROOSTERS Luk...

item.title: Lack of respect sparks Sea Eagles to roll Roosters - The Advertiser
item.description:
Lack of respect sparks Sea Eagles to roll Roosters  The Advertiser

On a night that delivered Trent Barrett the finest victory of his coaching career, the Sea Eagles ended the Roosters previously unbeaten run with a tough and thrilling 18-12 win. And it was the forgotten man of the NSW State of Origin debate who delivered the knockout blow, when Walker raced away with the match clincher with less than two minutes remaining. It follows Manly’s recent wins over North Queensland and Canterbury, that Walker believes have not received the respect they deserve. “The last couple of weeks I don’t think people were respecting us and respecting our wins,” Walker said...

item.title: SuperCoach: Mid-price game changers - The Advertiser
item.description:
SuperCoach: Mid-price game changers  The Advertiser

This year that may not be the case. For the sake of argument let’s define midpricers as those that can be had for between $300K and $400K, you won’t want all of these players in your squad, but the money you save by picking 3 or 4 from the list below over a proven gun can help you beef up your squad elsewhere. ROGER TUIVASA-SHECK FLB ($324,000) A former gun available for a bargain price, you are not taking a chance here you are getting a bargain. A fullback with a sensational base thanks to his workrate returning the ball, Tuivasa-Sheck rarely goes a game without either scoring or assisting...

item.title: Hair tests to head off cocaine - The Australian
item.description:
Hair tests to head off cocaine  The Australian

It is believed the NRL is also prepared to consider its introduction on a limited basis, heightening the chances that the game’s battle against illicit drugs could soon be expanded to include hair tests, which can detect substances such as cocaine up to three months after they are ingested. The sense of unanimity between the two bodies comes after a spate of incidents related to illicit drugs over the past week, the fallout from which continued yesterday when Gold Coast forward Kevin Proctor was sanctioned by the Titans, and two clubs — the Sydney Roosters and Cronulla — suffered financiall...

item.title: Blues team: Wallace injury opens door for rookie - The Advertiser
item.description:
Blues team: Wallace injury opens door for rookie  The Advertiser

Penrith hooker Peter Wallace is set to be robbed of a stunning comeback to State of Origin after sustaining a groin injury against Newcastle on Sunday. The injury has thrown NSW’s game one preparations into chaos. Gold Coast’s Nathan Peats is now the favourite ahead of South Sydney’s Robbie Farah. Wallace was on track to win the three-way battle for selection until he hobbled off after 16 minutes in Penrith’s 30-20 win over Newcastle. Wallace will have scans on Monday to determine the extent of his ­injury but he is long odds to play in Origin I on Wednesday week. LIKELY TEAM: Maroons shock...

item.title: Plea for refs to abolish calls - The Australian
item.description:
Plea for refs to abolish calls  The Australian

The day after Manly’s 22-10 elimination final loss to Penrith, Fittler and Johns both argued in some instances the bunker should be free to make ­decisions without having to give the benefit of the doubt to on-field referee calls. Manly coach Trent Barrett was left fuming following Saturday night’s loss at Allianz Stadium, when with scores locked at 10-10, Penrith centre Tyrone Peachey was ruled to not have knocked a ball on in the lead-up to a try with six minutes remaining. After the on-field call was sent up as a try, the bunker was unable to find conclusive evidence of whether the ball ...

item.title: Melbourne storms Brookvale - The Australian
item.description:
Melbourne storms Brookvale  The Australian

Defence went out the window on Saturday afternoon in the battle of Brookvale, as the two teams conceded a combined 11 tries, at an average of one every seven minutes. After a nine-try first half, the Sea Eagles scored the only two of the second half through forwards Jake Trbojevic and Brenton Lawrence, but the Storm controlled the final stages just as Manly threatened. Cameron Munster and Jesse Bromwich returned from injuries for Melbourne, but it was veteran fullback Billy Slater who was back to his best as the Storm ran riot early. Slater set up three first-half tries, including two withi...

item.title: Perfect 8 jackpot hits $145k - The Advertiser
item.description:
Perfect 8 jackpot hits $145k  The Advertiser

Here is a rundown on how easy it is to sign up. I mean, think of what you could do with all that cash … Last week, the Perfect 8 were: On to trying to win the massive $145k this week. Bulldogs v Broncos — Thursday 8.05pm at ANZ Stadium Ben Hunt HFB (Broncos) Hunt has flown under the radar yet again this season with all the limelight on Anthony Milford in recent weeks. Now priced at $400k with scores of 53, 77, 58 and 67 thus far for an average of 63.8PPG in the classic form of the game, Hunt is in terrific form. The Bulldogs were just carved up by DCE and the Sea Eagles and I expect the Bro...

item.title: Bunnies trounce Sea Eagles - The Australian
item.description:
Bunnies trounce Sea Eagles  The Australian

Walker was involved in everything at the Lottoland venue, scoring one try, setting up two others and breaking the line three times for the Rabbitohs in their first match without injured Greg Inglis. Robbie Farah also scored his first try in Rabbitohs colours, as the Bunnies consigned Manly to their seventh straight loss, and their fourth in a row at their former Brookvale fortress. After Manly led 12-0 early, Walker rescued the Bunnies with an incredible 11-minute streak before halftime. He provided the last pass for Robert Jennings in Souths’ opening try in the 18th minute, before he strol...

item.title: Sterling to pick NSW emerging camp - The Advertiser
item.description:
Sterling to pick NSW emerging camp  The Advertiser

The upcoming one-day induction will take greater significance in the new year after seven of the eight Blues debutants last series came through the pathway. Matt Moylan, Josh Mansour, Wade Graham, Dylan Walker, Adam Reynolds, Tyson Frizell, and Josh Mansour were all a part of the camp in either 2014 or 15. Jack Bird was the only rookie not to experience an emerging camp. It will be the first time Daley will meet with players after he was forced to abandon his traditional end-of-season catch-up due to the Four Nations tour. “They come back and they’re into the (Auckland) Nines. It was too di...

item.title: ‘He’s ready’: Bennett’s tip for NSW selectors - The Advertiser
item.description:
‘He’s ready’: Bennett’s tip for NSW selectors  The Advertiser

But the seven-time premier coach has got one tip for Blues selectors — pick try-scoring machine Jimmy ‘the Jet’ Roberts in the centres. “He’s ready,” Bennett declared when The Daily Telegraph sounded him out about his Brisbane Broncos flyer and his ability to lift to the next level in State of Origin football. Roberts is vying with Josh Dugan, Dylan Walker, Jack Bird and Joey Leilua for the right centre role. Despite his wayward off-field history, Bennett is convinced Roberts would step up to the mark. PEATS DOESN’T WANT TO TALK ORIGIN CRONK WILL DECIDE FUTURE AFTER ORIGIN Footy Pass promo ...

item.title: SuperCoach superfan gives his mate a lesson - The Advertiser
item.description:
SuperCoach superfan gives his mate a lesson  The Advertiser

The Sea Eagles routed the Rabbitohs on Friday night and Manly centre Dylan Walker was in the middle of everything in a dominant performance that saw him deliver three try-assists, seven tackle busts, two linebreaks one linebreak assist and 130 SuperCoach points. Watch the video below as SuperCoach superfan Steve Byrnes serves it up to his mate Corey Stephenson - Corey made the unfortunate decision to NOT pick Dylan Walker... That my friends is genuine passion!

item.title: Wilfred’s fearless predictions for Round 14 - The Advertiser
item.description:
Wilfred’s fearless predictions for Round 14  The Advertiser

You just know that you’ll leave out that one player who goes large. But hey, that’s part of the fun of SuperCoach isn’t it? Backing your own judgment and making calls on who will and won’t score well from each week. Just as an aside, apologies for the lack of predictions last week as I had been travelling and then was unwell; but I’m all good now and raring to go again. Let’s look at Round 14. The Sea Eagles will comfortably account for the Knights / Taupau and JTurbo 75+ It’s not a fearless prediction by any means but there’s not much else I can come up with out of this game. The wet weath...

item.title: Tom Destroyevic does the job - The Australian
item.description:
Tom Destroyevic does the job  The Australian

Manly set up the commanding victory by scoring six first-half tries that left the Rabbitohs panting for breath. They ended up with nine in all, including four to reborn winger Akuila Uate — the second time he’s achieved the feat in his NRL career. He can thank his inside man, centre Dylan Walker, who set him up beautifully each time. Coincidently Uate’s last foursome was also against Souths, when he was in Newcastle colours in 2011. “I had been saying I wanted to get him over the line a bit more, but bloody hell he got four tonight. So he owes me a couple now,” Walker told Triple M. “Our st...

item.title: Trials wrap: Shattering injury, surprise belting - The Advertiser
item.description:
Trials wrap: Shattering injury, surprise belting  The Advertiser

With four fascinating match ups completing the pre-season for eight teams, here’s what went down and what to keep an eye on for the fortnight ahead. Panthers 18 (Martin, Latu, Whare tries, Cleary 3 goals) defeat Eels 6 (French try, Gutherson goal)at Pepper Stadium Standouts: Penrith head into the 2017 season with very few question marks hanging over them but perhaps the most significant one is whether or not Te Maire Martin can improve Penrith’s already formidable spine. If his performance against the Eels is anything to go by, the answer is an emphatic ‘yes’. Martin set up two tries and co...

item.title: How to rebuild an NRL club - The Advertiser
item.description:
How to rebuild an NRL club  The Advertiser

But given he didn’t say our chat was off the ­record, I thought I’d pass on some of it. This is not about Fulton blowing his own trumpet. This is about giving a 69-year-old rugby league Immortal his share of credit for this amazing Manly rebuild. It got me thinking this week when I saw Akuila Uate was up against his former club Newcastle for the first time tomorrow night. Uate is back in the type of form that made him a NSW and Australian Test winger. The irony is the Knights are still paying about half Uate’s wage. But before we tell you about how that deal came about, let’s tell you a sto...

item.title: Norman closes in on Top End return - The Advertiser
item.description:
Norman closes in on Top End return  The Advertiser

Norman, one of three big names listed in the No. 21 jersey for this weekend’s matches, will fly to Darwin on Wednesday with several other high-profile Eels also under an injury cloud. Originally slated for a return in round 17 after the bye round, Norman remains optimistic about his chances of playing against North Queensland and possibly Johnathan Thurston in the Top End. TEAMS: All the squad news for NRL Round 14 KENT: When does rugby league end? Eels coach Brad Arthur would welcome the return of Norman given the club’s casualty ward had suddenly become standing room only. “We’ll give Cor...

item.title: Manly preparing for another rebuild - The Advertiser
item.description:
Manly preparing for another rebuild  The Advertiser

Coach Trent Barrett has individual pieces needed to assemble a competitive football team. We look at five key areas Barrett and his side need to work on over the off-season in our Summer School series. FINAL VERDICT: Manly have some work to do Can they improve in the middle? The Sea Eagles have lacked mongrel upfront in recent seasons. Last year Martin Taupau, Nate Myles and Darcy Lussick were signed on to help revive their go-forward. Taupau showed glimpses of his rampaging best, Lussick had bursts of form but Myles hardly set the world on fire. The tenacious Jake Trbojevic tried hard all ...

item.title: Trying to find the culprit for Manly's embarrassment against the Dragons - ABC News
item.description:
Trying to find the culprit for Manly's embarrassment against the Dragons  ABC News

The Sea Eagles have suffered one of the worst brain fades you are likely to see this NRL season. Just two minutes into their 35-10 loss to the Dragons, Matthew Wright fielded a grubber near his goalline and took the tackle. It seemed a routine moment that happens any number of times in a rugby league game, but when Wright got up to play the ball, there was no-one there, resulting in an embarrassing try. External Link: Gareth Widdop capitalises on Manly's brain fade Granted, it is not the sole reason the Sea Eagles were brushed aside on Saturday, but it certainly did not help start the game ...

item.title: DCE dazzles as Manly dominate Cronulla - The Advertiser
item.description:
DCE dazzles as Manly dominate Cronulla  The Advertiser

The Sea Eagles secured their biggest scalp of the season with a convincing six tries to three win at Southern Cross Group Stadium. It was Manly’s fourth consecutive win and takes them to 22 competition points which puts them into fourth spot ahead of the Sharks on percentages. Pacquiao vs. Horn promo (small) Manly were awesome across the park with Martin Taupau and Jake Trbojevic leading the way in the middle while underrated hooker Api Koroisau was absolutely outstanding. That dominance in the forwards allowed Daly-Cherry-Evans and Blake Green to dictate the terms of the match while Dylan ...

item.title: One way NRL Bunker must improve - The Advertiser
item.description:
One way NRL Bunker must improve  The Advertiser

Tennis has Hawkeye. Racing has for the past 80 years put a line down for photo finishes to determine a result. Soccer has goal-line technology. All to protect the integrity of their sports. Rugby league has a useless multimillion-dollar bunker that can’t even run a line across a TV screen to determine if a player is offside or a pass has gone forward. Technology that is available for a few ­dollars on a mobile phone app. And it could have changed the outcome of two finals over the weekend — first, when Melbourne Storm winger Josh Addo-Carr scored from a blatant forward pass and, again, on S...

item.title: Hey Queensland, the party is over - The Advertiser
item.description:
Hey Queensland, the party is over  The Advertiser

The NSW Blues are now struggling to squeeze in an unprecedented number of in-form stars lining up for Origin selection. Usually, Blues coach Laurie Daley has a pool of about 25 players to choose from — this year he will have well over 50. And this while Queensland is battling to find players with Matt Scott and Greg Inglis gone for the season and Johnathan Thurston busted. The NSW hooking spot is one problem area but there is plenty of cover in every other position. And it’s all quality. Back-rower and centre look particularly strong. Look at the centre options — Jarryd Hayne, Josh Morris, ...

item.title: Best and worst of 2016 honoured in end-of-year awards - ABC News
item.description:
Best and worst of 2016 honoured in end-of-year awards  ABC News

They're back! The awards that stop a nation, or at least kill a couple of minutes on the train, return as Australia's heroes and zeroes are honoured in style. And what a year 2016 was. There was drought-breaking fairytales, athletes and teams rising to fame and fortune, unforgettable Olympic memories and a whole heap of stupid stuff to keep us entertained. These awards celebrate all of that, the good and the bad of Australian sport. There are some new prizes to be handed out among a stack of returning ones from last year. The red carpet has been rolled out, and our recipients are looking da...

item.title: Watch: Ugly strike on DWZ missed by refs - The Advertiser
item.description:
Watch: Ugly strike on DWZ missed by refs  The Advertiser

Bad blood between the two sides boiled over when Wright lunged and hit Watene- Zelezniak during Penrith’s upset victory at Allianz Stadium on Saturday night. Fairfax Media published images of the incident and the Kiwi international said despite appearances otherwise, the Sea Eagles winger didn’t strike him with a clenched fist. WATCH THE INCIDENT IN THE VIDEO PLAYER ABOVE. “It was more of a palm, it didn’t really rattle me too much,” Watene-Zelezniak told AAP. “There was a lot of banter but I try not to get caught up in that too much or else I lose focus on my own game. “I just tried to giv...

item.title: Roosters, Manly into finals - The Australian
item.description:
Roosters, Manly into finals  The Australian

The Titans appeared to have pulled off one of the upsets of the season on Saturday afternoon when stand-in captain Kevin Proctor’s try gave his team a 16-6 advantage with 20 minutes to go. But the Roosters roared back into the contest on the back of Michael Gordon’s 70th-minute try, before Boyd Cordner levelled the match off a Mitchell Pearce short ball. Gordon nailed the tricky conversion and then kicked a penalty goal in the final minute to seal a thrilling 20-16 victory for the 11,212 crowd, as well as second spot to finish the season. They have a date with the Broncos at Allianz Stadium...

item.title: NRL police probe targets stunning fraud claim - The Advertiser
item.description:
NRL police probe targets stunning fraud claim  The Advertiser

A report in The Daily Telegraph claims police believe they have discovered cases of spot fixing, money laundering and illegal third-party payments across multiple teams as part of an investigation into alleged match fixing. The report also claims police are looking at whether players have backed themselves in exotic markets, while others are said to have possibly passed on vital inside information to gamblers. It comes just months after the NRL deregistered former Wests Tigers centre Tim Simona when he was found to have placed numerous bets on himself in matches last season. The NRL is yet ...

item.title: Matty Johns’ NSW Origin team - The Advertiser
item.description:
Matty Johns’ NSW Origin team  The Advertiser

Queensland are vulnerable. The Maroons will rightfully stay loyal to this champion squad, but father time is still undefeated. In 2017 I’ve witnessed champion playmakers Johnathan Thurston and Cooper Cronk having difficulty against fast-moving, aggressive defences. The key to beating this ageing champion isn’t through picking players with experience, it’s through picking fearless young players who are in form and at their physical peak. Our selection policies haven’t worked. We still favour players with State of Origin experience, but it’s losing experience. Yes there are a few experienced ...

item.title: Manly recover to beat Warriors - The Australian
item.description:
Manly recover to beat Warriors  The Australian

Shaun Johnson had a chance to level the scores in the second-last minute when he sprinted 40m but he was dragged over the sideline by Akuila Uate to end any hopes of a Warriors’ win. It’s the Warriors’ ninth straight loss in Perth and the fifth time they have let slip a considerable lead at nib Stadium. The long trip also came at a cost, with forward Albert Vete suffering a broken arm, while Ryan Hoffman was a late withdrawal with a broken foot. Tom Trbojevic scored twice for Manly and Daly Cherry-Evans controlled the win and set up two tries in his last audition before Queensland name thei...

item.title: Footy craziness in season-first bonanza - The Advertiser
item.description:
Footy craziness in season-first bonanza  The Advertiser

After the Dragons created the biggest half-time lead of the season at 30-0, Manly scored four tries in the first 16 minutes after the break to reduce the margin to eight. Incredibly, three of the Sea Eagles’ tries came while they were down to 12 men after prop Darcy Lussick was sin-binned for punching Dragons lock Jack de Belin. The firebrand Manly prop was also put on report for a possible headbutt. But when Nene Macdonald leapt high to mark a Daly Cherry-Evans kick and claim a seven-tackle set, the match swung back in the Dragons’ favour. Paul Vaughan barged over in the following set, bef...

item.title: Monday Buzz: Highlights, lowlights - The Advertiser
item.description:
Monday Buzz: Highlights, lowlights  The Advertiser

HIGHLIGHT No player in the NRL has been under more media scrutiny than Manly skipper Daly Cherry-Evans. Two weeks ago he was apparently a $10 million flop. Since then he’s outpointed Johnathan Thurston and carved up the Canterbury Bulldogs on Saturday afternoon. A potentially great player now looks like becoming one. MORE MONDAY BUZZ: How long does Des Hasler have left? HIGHLIGHT II Despite the peptide scandal, an incredible 60,000 members signed up with the Essendon Bombers for 2017. Their loyalty was rewarded with a fantastic first-up win over AFL giants Hawthorn. LOWLIGHT The pathetic pe...

item.title: NRL SuperCoach Cheapie Bible - The Advertiser
item.description:
NRL SuperCoach Cheapie Bible  The Advertiser

WELL, thanks to the dictionary you now all know what this article is about. Hopefully for our sake though, this ‘inferior quality’ rubbish is just plain wrong. By way of qualification, any player priced below $200,000 falls into this bracket. The way to all SuperCoaches’ hearts is earning us big cash, or scoring huge points. As such, the ultimate combination we look for come the first Team List Tuesday (TLT) is rookie priced players who can tick both boxes! But ust because a cheapie is named, doesn’t make them a good pick for your SuperCoach team. Traps like poor roles, minimal minutes, sho...

item.title: Who to select as your SuperCoach captain - The Advertiser
item.description:
Who to select as your SuperCoach captain  The Advertiser

Shameless plug there, as the stars aligned for Billy Slater (134 points) to absolutely torch the Knights and his 8.1% of owners will have been shouting LOOPHOLE at the top of their lungs last Friday night — no doubt in public with innocent bystanders thinking … What’s this guy on about?! Little did they know that you had just pulled off one of the great moves of the 2017 SuperCoach season. For those that missed Billy, all the top mentions last week in Taumololo (82), Merrin (72) and Rapana (132!) delivered in the absence of armband regulars in Gallen and Burgess. A full compliment of teams ...

item.title: Firing Turbo a fillip for two - The Australian
item.description:
Firing Turbo a fillip for two  The Australian

Trbojevic hurt his ankle and knee in the Sea Eagles’ loss to Brisbane four weeks ago. It was deemed a six to eight week injury but the young fullback is back running at full strength and was named yesterday on Trent Barrett’s extended bench to play Newcastle on Friday at Lottoland. While naming the 20-year-old is acknowledgment of his solid progress in rehab, Barrett might also be tempted to give him one more week off as Manly have the bye in round 15. But with new left-side winger Jorge Taufua gone for the season with a torn anterior cruciate ligament, the back three might need to be bolst...

item.title: NRL live: Souths host Broncos after Manly upsets Raiders in golden point - ABC News
item.description:
NRL live: Souths host Broncos after Manly upsets Raiders in golden point  ABC News

South Sydney faces off against the Brisbane Broncos after Manly takes down Canberra with an extra-time penalty goal. Follow our live commentary and stats in our NRL ScoreCentre. Quick navigation - Raiders 18-20 Manly - Rabbitohs v Broncos Rabbitohs v Broncos Live stream v Rabbitohs v Broncos live from 7:50pm AEST Live summary External Link: Rabbitohs v Broncos summary Live chalkboard External Link: Rabbitohs v Broncos chalkboard Live stats External Link: Rabbitohs v Broncos stats Raiders v Manly Photo: Dylan Walker missed a few chances to ice the game, but stood up when it counted. (AAP: Lu...

item.title: Wilfred’s SuperCoach wrap: Round 8 - The Advertiser
item.description:
Wilfred’s SuperCoach wrap: Round 8  The Advertiser

Raiders v Sea Eagles (18—20) Match report What an exciting and somewhat unexpected finish to this golden point game — penalties in golden point? Surely not! But yes, that’s exactly what happened, with Dylan Walker given the chance to make amends for his last two relatively easy misses of a penalty and conversion. Somewhat controversial was the Junior Paulo no-try ruling by the Bunker, which based on precedent as recent as last week (the Gallen try), should clearly have been awarded. Anyway, let’s highlight some of the key SuperCoach performers and flops. The Good Josh Papalii (91) Papa’s gr...

item.title: 2017 Auckland Nines squads, draw - The Advertiser
item.description:
2017 Auckland Nines squads, draw  The Advertiser

Jarryd Hayne, Shaun Johnson and Johnathan Thurston have all been confirmed and will no doubt dazzle fans over the first weekend of February. Rabbitohs coach Michael Maguire confirmed on Tuesday halfback Adam Reynolds won’t play due to hamstring tightness. On Thursday, Dragons forward Tyson Frizell withdrew with a back injury and he’ll be replaced by Jacob Host. Parramatta’s rampaging winger Semi Radradra, who initially had surrendered his passport as part of his bail conditions, has been allowed to travel across the ditch. Dylan Walker was added to Manly’s squad after Matthew Wright fractur...

item.title: Manly’s moves are mystifying - The Advertiser
item.description:
Manly’s moves are mystifying  The Advertiser

This manifested itself fully in 2016 with the club finishing 13th, their worst result since 2004. Players like the Stewart brothers, Anthony Watmough, Kieran Foran, Matt Ballin and Steve Matai have all departed, either for other clubs or retirement and the moves the club has made to replace them seems to be lacking in focus. Ballin, for example, was re-signed to a two-year contract extension early in 2015 and was then released at the end of the season. Matai and Brett Stewart were eventually beaten by injuries and the club has been forced to apply to the NRL for medical exemptions so their ...

item.title: Barrett proving his worth as Sea Eagles sizzle - The Advertiser
item.description:
Barrett proving his worth as Sea Eagles sizzle  The Advertiser

At the start of the season hardly anyone gave Barrett a hope of lasting the year. Then Manly lost their opening two games and the knives were out. At about that time a backroom brawl erupted between football head Bob Fulton and new chief executive Tim Cleary. The joint was in turmoil. Bozo knew nothing about recruiting, Barrett knew even less about coaching. Fast forward seven weeks and look at them now. Sitting in the top eight on 10 competition points going into the rep weekend and among their scalps this season include the Cowboys, Bulldogs, Roosters, Raiders and now the Rabbitohs. Last ...

item.title: ‘Rotten’ Rabbitohs ripped apart - The Advertiser
item.description:
‘Rotten’ Rabbitohs ripped apart  The Advertiser

That’s the message coming from the rugby league experts after a demoralising 46-8 defeat at the hands of Manly Fox Sports commentator Braith Anasta said South Sydney don’t look like showing signs of improvement and don’t have any reinforcements of note to call upon to help salvage their season. “It was abysmal the first half,” Anasta said. “You look at the Rabbitohs’, and sure they’re missing Greg Inglis, but they’ve only really got George Burgess out with suspension. “That’s the main concern. Who comes back next week? — well no one. It’s worrying signs for the Bunnies.” Anasta’s commentary...

item.title: Daly’s golden boot sinks Raiders - The Australian
item.description:
Daly’s golden boot sinks Raiders  The Australian

Daly Cherry-Evans’s field goal four minutes into golden-point extra time finally snuffed out a courageous Canberra 21-20. The Raiders had rallied from 20-6 down at halftime to put on two tries while reduced to 15 men, with forwards Shannon Boyd and Dunamis Lui both suffering knee injuries. It was left to skipper Jarrod Croker to kick a sideline penalty, under pressure, with 31 seconds of the game left to force extra time at 20-20. And that’s where the fightback ended. For the second time this season, Canberra have lost a match in golden point time to Manly. “I’m good friends with Sticky (co...

item.title: Injury threatens Wallace dream - The Australian
item.description:
Injury threatens Wallace dream  The Australian

Wallace limped from the field during his side’s win over Newcastle yesterday and will undergo scans this morning. While Penrith officials remain optimistic, it appears Wallace is fighting a losing battle to prove his fitness in time for Origin I at Suncorp Stadium on May 31. Wallace was understood to have the edge on Peats and incumbent Robbie Farah heading into the weekend but injury threatens to once again derail coach Laurie Daley’s master-plan to unseat the Maroons. In the absence of Wallace, Daley has a straight decision between the past and the future. Farah is closer to the end than ...

item.title: Bunnies have nobody to blame - The Advertiser
item.description:
Bunnies have nobody to blame  The Advertiser

For the Bunnies reckon The Bunker is bad? C’mon. At least that disaster only costs $2 million to run. But to put an NRL team in the paddock — it’s three times as much plus change. And, yes, of course we’re taking the you-know-what. For undoubtedly the Bunnies were robbed last week against Brisbane. And courtesy of clangers. But on Friday? They were terrible. Bunkeresque, even. A performance best highlighted by that giant hand which, belonging to Manly prop Brenton Lawrence, embedded itself deep into the chest of Bunnies halfback Adam Reynolds as he charged towards the tryline for the first ...

item.title: Sharks hooked by an injury crisis - The Australian
item.description:
Sharks hooked by an injury crisis  The Australian

Last year’s premiers were blown off their home ground in the opening 20 minutes by Manly but on a day when very little went right for the Sharks, the biggest setback was suffered in the second half when hooker Jayden Brailey left the field with a broken jaw. The 21-year-old has been a mainstay of the Sharks side this year but he made a hasty exit to the sidelines with blood coming from his mouth after attempting to tackle Sea Eagles centre Dylan Walker. Brailey was rushed to hospital in an ambulance and faces a decent stint on the sidelines. The club had a ready-made replacement in Daniel M...

item.title: Win big: Perfect 8 jackpot hits $140k - The Advertiser
item.description:
Win big: Perfect 8 jackpot hits $140k  The Advertiser

Here is a rundown on how easy it is to sign up! I mean, think of what you could do with all that cash … Last week, the Perfect 8 were: On to trying to win the massive $140k this week. Rabbitohs v Roosters: Thursday 8.05pm at ANZ Stadium Cody Walker FLB | 5/8 (Rabbitohs) Walker is a freak, plain and simple. Every single time he has the ball he looks like scoring, particularly whenever he has played at fullback — where he is this Thursday night against the Roosters. When in the No. 1 jersey last season, Walker produced scores of 92, 91, 100, 36, 79, 65, 50 and 55 for an average of 71PPG. I li...

item.title: Late Mail: Des rolls dice with Dogs reshuffle - The Advertiser
item.description:
Late Mail: Des rolls dice with Dogs reshuffle  The Advertiser

BULLDOGS v SEA EAGLES 4pm Sunday at ANZ Stadium Bulldogs: 1. William Hopoate 2. Brett Morris 3. Josh Morris 4. Brenko Lee 5. Marcelo Montoya 6. Matt Frawley 9. Moses Mbye 8. Aiden Tolman 17. Michael Lichaa 10. James Graham 11. Josh Jackson 12. Adam Elliot 13. David Klemmer. Interchange: 7. Chase Stanley 14. Francis Tualau 15. Raymond Faitala-Mariner 16. Moses Mbye moves to halfback and Michael Lichaa returns as starting hooker, with C...

item.title: How Baz turned 25-year omen into Manly riches - The Advertiser
item.description:
How Baz turned 25-year omen into Manly riches  The Advertiser

Twelve months later, and the Sea Eagles are back in the NRL’s top four with the best attacking record in the competition. Manly’s 35-18 flogging of defending premiers Cronulla on Sunday was the fifth time they have scored 30 or more this season. According to the Fox Sports Lab, captain Daly Cherry-Evans is now second in the competition for try assists (18), while five-eighth Blake Green has forced the most line dropouts (15). Live stream the 2017 NRL Telstra Premiership on FOX SPORTS. Get your free 2-week FOXTEL NOW trial and start watching in minutes. SIGN UP NOW! In the middle, Martin Tau...

item.title: Storm hang on in Lottoland thriller - The Advertiser
item.description:
Storm hang on in Lottoland thriller  The Advertiser

Thanks to a scintillating double from winger Suliasi Vunivulu, a far from perfect Melbourne side held on to record a hard fought 30-26 victory over the Sea Eagles on Saturday. Manly have now lost consecutive matches at Brookvale, meaning they have claimed just four wins at their one-time Fortress in the past 15 months. The Sea Eagles, though, deserve huge praise for refusing to give up despite trailing 18-0 after as many minutes in the first half. They also trailed 30-16 at halftime. SKIPPER: Why Daley must look for Cordner ESCAPE: Brisbane’s incredible game-winner But in a week when the cl...

item.title: When will Penrith take the leap? - The Advertiser
item.description:
When will Penrith take the leap?  The Advertiser

The above sentence could describe both the 2016 and 2017 seasons for the Panthers. Twelve months on, Penrith remain in the same position as they were in this time last year — can 2018 be the year the can stops getting kicked down the road? WHERE THEY FINISHED Penrith came in at seventh after the regular season, winning 13 games and losing 11 after winning 14 and losing 10 in 2016. A controversial but deserved win over Manly precipitated a 13-6 loss to the Broncos at Suncorp Stadium, consigning the Panthers to 6th place overall for the second year in a row. WHAT WENT WRONG? The start to the ...

item.title: Fatima Kdouh’s SuperCoach team - The Advertiser
item.description:
Fatima Kdouh’s SuperCoach team  The Advertiser

They can no longer use inexperience as an excuse for a mediocre finish. I’ve gone with a mix of youth and experience and recruited big guns like Cameron Smith, Shaun Johnson, Johnathan Thurston and Andrew Fifita and exciting youngsters like Nick Cotric, Jai Field and Siosifa Talakai. Bring on SuperCoach 2017! HOOKER Cameron Smith ($523,700) OK, so I have a confession to make, this is the first year I’ve started with Cameron Smith. In the past I’ve opted to look for value, someone who could be a decent POD proposition. It’s safe to say that experiment is now dead in the water. This time I’m ...

item.title: NRL SuperCoach study guide: Sea Eagles - The Advertiser
item.description:
NRL SuperCoach study guide: Sea Eagles  The Advertiser

The last veterans from the Des Hasler era are nearing the end and Trent Barrett is trying to rebuild a team who suffered a serious fall from premiership relevance in 2016. As you can see from the team below, picking their best 17 is very difficult given the amount of moving parts around the side. However, there is still some SuperCoach gold to be had so read on to discover who can make the difference for you in 2017. MORE SUPERCOACH: SuperCoach study guides for every club Winners and losers from price reveals VK picks his best PODs Champion’s hot tips for 2017 10 most expensive in each posi...
